Award.AwardTitle: Nanoscience and Engineering Center (NSEC) for Directed Assembly of Nanostructures

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering Center for Directed Assembly of Nanostructures (NSEC) (www.nano.rpi.edu) was founded on September 1, 2001 at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in collaboration with the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and Los Alamos National Laboratory; it ended on September 31, 2012. Our NSEC addressed challenges in designing and synthesizing nanostructured materials and developed dramatically improved capabilities for many industrial and biomedical applications. Directed assembly is the fundamental gateway to the success of nanotechnology. Hence, our NSEC combined theory and computational modeling with experimentation to discover the means to assemble nanoscale building blocks with unique properties into functional structures under well-controlled, intentionally directed conditions. Our NSEC integrated research, education, and technology dissemination to serve as a leading national and international resource for fundamental knowledge and applications in nanoscale science and technology. We produced over one thousand publications with well over ten thousand citations thus far, nearly seventy patents and applications, more than seventy doctorates, four start-up companies, the Molecularium® Project for science literacy, and presented over two thousand talks throughout the world.

Our research program consisted of three coordinated interdisciplinary thrusts: Thrust 1: Nanoparticle Gels and Polymer Nanocomposites focused on the synthesis and assembly of nanoparticles with like or unlike surfaces using chemical and/or physical control to create materials with novel properties. Its efforts resulted in a unified experimental and theoretical understanding of nanoparticle-polymer systems, from nanoparticle gels to polymer nanocomposites, conceptually bridging for the first time the fields of colloid and polymer science. Organic and inorganic nanoscale building blocks with controlled size, composition, shape and surface functionality were synthesized, and the fundamental viscoelasticity, phase behavior and structure of nanoparticle suspensions and mixtures were studied. We created 3D structures using direct-write assembly of nanoparticle inks, and assembled, characterized and modeled the behavior of diverse polymer nanocomposites. Thrust 2: Nanostructured Biomolecule Composite Architectures focused on incorporating biological molecules and synthetic nanoscale building blocks into nanocomposites to create novel functional assemblies to enable applications in tissue engineering, bio-sensing, self-cleaning and self-repair. Major fundamental advances were made: (1) discovery of the effect of nanoscale size and curvature on biomolecule stability and function; and (2) mechanistic understanding through theory and experiment of multiscale phase behavior leading to functional biomolecule composite nanostructure assemblies. We also discovered the ‘rules’ of interaction and self-assembly using electrostatic effects in water, which have considerable implications and impact for problems in alternative energy. Thrust 3: Serving Society through Education and Outreach: (1) increased public science literacy through informal and formal education, integrating nanotechnology research with education, and (2) enhanced the safe and efficient transfer of nanotechnology developments to industry.
